Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Collaborative Research: Minimally Invasive Robotic Non-Destructive Evaluation and Rehabilitation for Bridge Decks (Bridge-MINDER)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Bridges are critical components of modern transportation infrastructure. Bridges deteriorate over time as a result of material aging, excessive use and overloading, environmental conditions, inadequate maintenance, and deficiencies in inspection and evaluation. Building on the recent advances in robotics and automation technologies, the objective of this project is to develop a novel Minimally Invasive robotic Non-Destructive Evaluation and Rehabilitation for bridge decks.

The project develops new robotic system, algorithms and control schemes for sustainable civil infrastructure, including (1) development of a novel robotics-assisted in-traffic system for highly-efficient, safety-guaranteed bridge deck inspection and diagnosis; (2) development of a new robotic rehabilitation system for delivering fast, cost-effective, minimally invasive repair and maintenance for bridge decks; (3) a human-in-the-loop robotic coordination for minimally traffic interference; and (4) experimental platforms and field performance evaluation for the proposed system. The project also provides insights to advance real time scene understanding, multiple robot coordination, and human-robot collaboration in complex robotic systems. If successful, this project can drastically reduce bridge maintenance cost and mitigate negative impact caused by closing the bridge traffic flow under traditional bridge inspection and repair. The project outcomes, including source code, datasets, and publications, are to be shared among research community and the general public. The project also includes a number of integrated research and education programs to attract students from underrepresented groups into engineering and involve students into robotics research.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University New Brunswick
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bridges are critical infrastructure components for the safety of the traveling public and the sustainability of the economic activities. More than 600,000 bridges in the United States have been subjected to extreme deterioration due to various mechanical and weather conditions, inadequate maintenance, and deficiencies in inspection and evaluation. The potential economic and social impacts of these deteriorating bridges to the general public are enormous. For example, according to the US Federal Highway Administration (FHWA), the cost of repairing and replacing deteriorating highway bridges in US is estimated at more than $140 billion in 2008. Effective health monitoring, repair and rehabilitation of the deteriorating bridge components are necessary to ensure the transportation safety. Non-destructive evaluation (NDE) are effective ways to reliably identify and predict early-stage bridge deterioration to enable proactive interventions for repair and rehabilitation. The delivery of the current NDE technologies cannot meet the increasing demands for highly-efficient, cost-effective and safety-guaranteed inspection and evaluation. The objective of this project is to develop a novel minimally Invasive robotic non-destructive evaluation and rehabilitation for bridge decks.

Over the past five years, the PIs have accomplished a various research tasks to develop new robotic platform and algorithms for delivering highly efficient robotic bridge deck inspection, evaluation, and rehabilitation systems. The main outcomes of the project lie in several aspects: (1) a multi-modality NDE system for highly-efficient and safety-guaranteed bridge deck inspection and diagnosis; (2) a new robotic rehabilitation system for delivering fast, cost-effective, minimally invasive repair and maintenance for bridge deck; and (3) experimental validation and field deployment for the developed robotic inspection and rehabilitation systems. More than 10 journal and conference publications have been produced and supported by the project. A number of research activities were integrated into the education programs to attract students from underrepresented groups into engineering fields, such as participating the Rutgers TARGET and SUPER programs, supporting more than 3 senior design projects, and attracting more than 10 undergraduate students to conduct research assistance. Additionally, the PIs also initiated and built collaborative efforts with robotics researchers in UK in the last year of the project supported partially through the US/Europe Collaboration supplement.

 


Last Modified: 04/26/2020
Modified by: Jingang Yi

  • The developed bridge deck rehabilitation robotic system performed a field testing and validation on a bridge in New Jersey.

A number of research activities were integrated into the education programs to attract students from underrepresented groups into engineering fields, such as participating the Rutgers TARGET and SUPER programs, supporting more than 3 senior design projects, and attracting more than 10 undergraduate students to conduct research assistance. Additionally, the PIs also initiated and built collaborative efforts with robotics researchers in UK in the last year of the project supported partially through the US/Europe Collaboration supplement.
